displaytitle: A portrait of Mian Hadala Pal (r. 1673–78)
medium: Opaque watercolor with gold on paper
dimensionsproposed: Proposed frame (Louis XVI black): 54.6 × 41.9 × 3.8 cm (21 1/2 × 16 1/2 × 1 1/2 in.)
creditline: Museum purchase, Mary Tumbull Adams Art Fund
inscribed: inscribed in Devanagari with gold ink

titles.title: A portrait of Mian Hadala Pal (r. 1673–78)

makers.displaydate: ca. 1710–1778; born Guler, Himachal Pradesh, India; died Basohli, India
makers.displaymaker: Attributed to Nainsukh of Basohli, ca. 1710–1778; born Guler, Himachal Pradesh, India; died Basohli, India

texts.textentryhtml: The nobleman Mian Hadala Pal is depicted in profile, elegantly kneeling on a floral carpet placed on an outdoor terrace. Based on the inscription above the sitter’s head, the painting has been attributed to Nainsukh, one of the most widely celebrated artists of the Punjab Hills in northwestern India. His innovative work is distinguished by his mastery of portraiture; his absorption of Mughal painting techniques, including its methods for depicting depth; and his interest in Hindu subjects. Nainsukh’s tremendous ability to capture gesture and detail is seen here in his portrayal of a fleeting moment when the nobleman subtly touches his punch dagger, as though wishing to make a slight adjustment to its placement.

Collection of Theodore Allen Heinrich (1910–1981); Private Collection, Toronto, until 2018; [Waddington's Auctioneers & Appraisers, Toronto, Indian Miniature Paintings from an Important Toronto Estate, December 1–6, 2018, lot 16: “Rajasthan School, Portrait of a Seated Prince, 19th Century”]; purchased by Kapoor Galleries from [Waddington's Auctioneers & Appraisers, Toronto], December 6, 2018–2021; acquired by the Princeton University Art Museum, 2021.
